Name: acetic acid production, methanol carboxylation (Monsanto), product in 98% solution state | propionic acid | EN15804GD, U
Category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals
Description: The Monsanto process, with rhodium catalyst and methyl iodide promoter, catalyzes the carbonylation of methanol and is one of the most widely adopted technologies for the global production of acetic acid (Althaus, 2007), the reaction of which is as follows:;CH3OH + CO → CH3COOH, ΔH = -0.1386 MJ;The older BASF process uses a cobalt catalyst. In 2000, BP has started producing acetic acid using the Cativa process, which uses a promoted iridium catalyst package instead of the rhodium complex. (Jones, 2000);The operating conditions of this homogeneous catalytic carbonylation reaction (Monsanto process) spans from 30–60 bar and at temperatures of 150–200 °C and gives selectivity of over 99% based on methanol (Le Berre,2014). Methanol carbonylation in polar solvents is preferred (i.e., acetic acid/water solvent medium). A small amount of methanol may be loss due to side reactions with propionic acid as the main product. The carbon monoxide is lost in the reaction with water to carbon dioxide and hydrogen.;In this dataset, a yield of 95% was assumed.;References:;Le Berre, C., Serp, P., Kalck, P. and Torrence, G. P. 2014. Acetic Acid. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.;Jones, Jane H. "The Cativa™ process for the manufacture of acetic acid." Platinum Metals Review 44.3 (2000): 94-105.;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.0 No. 8. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
